comments.text: Steve, this is one of the most negative crap reviews for a card that almost doubles the framrate of my tuf Rtx 3060 ti at only $50 us dollars more. You went out of your way to show the Rtx 5070 in its worst light, showing it at 4k in the most demanding games. Only  a fool would think this is a product for that, which doesn't mean it doesn't have worth, as it is as fast as a Rtx 3090. Sure it should have more vram,  but I don't know if you realize there's not much better out there for $550. Anyway I went to microcenter after one of their $750 asus prime 5070 ti cards advertised, they had 2 already sold and a case full $950 overclocked prime 5070 ti. To be clear I can afford ANY CARD I want but refuse to be scalped even by the manufacturer, so I settled for a Pny Rtx 5070 triplefan OC for $550 and lucky to get it in this market. Not quite as nice as my Asus tuf cards but nice and okay for a spare computer.  Will it play every game at any setting or resolution,  of course not but it doesn't have to. Wishing you all my best Lou.

comments.text:
Given your pretty extreme 12GB video, I would expect this to get a special empasis in the review of this card and investigation of how serious your stance on this is here (show it, prove it, the "problem" is, one doesn't see the issue).
According to your other video, the results would be simply impossible. Even with just 8-9GB usage, there was often a 100% performance difference between the 4060 Ti with 8GB and 16GB. There is not a hint of this here. That's why, even if it doesn't show, you actually need to make a deep dive on this.
Edit: Well, okay you have Indiana Jones. Still it's baffling how anything else seems unaffected. Also perhaps the most stupidly demanding game of all, that monkey game, which AMD apparently still can't handle.

comments.text:
Before raytracing. Everyone was apples to apples. What fps could this card run it at 4k ultra etc and what fps can the new card run it at those same settings. But now with ray tracing and dlss it's different. Why would me, as someone who has a 3070 who cannot play the witcher 3 on ultra with no raytracing smoothly with more than maybe a 50 frame average with dlss on performance, upgrade to a 5070 when I still can't even turn on ray tracing, with raytracing on low and dlss switched to balanced I would be getting even worse perfoemance than I am now just for a very minor image improvement.

Any card needs to have enough of a performance increase where we can turn on these settings without crippling our performance to even worse than they are now.

A 5080 from what I have seen in videos can get 60fps in the witcher at 4k with raytracing fully on but you still need dlss on balanced to do it and in novigrad it still dips down into the 50s.

We deserved a better generation, maybe a refreshed 5080 with a further 25% perforomance increase will finally put it over the hill of what current and recent games require. But I'm not upgrading until I can get the sort of performance upgrade we used to expect. Generational improvements, not incremental.

comments.text:
We used to have False Advertising laws against this crap. But for decades they've (Marketing Companies and Corporations) have been pushing the boundaries further and further. The amount of Deception in Marketing is huge. What we are saying isn't a lie if you word it like this ********** etc. Thats why many ads don't claim things but insinuate them. It also saves them from Lawsuits!

So they skirt the laws and push shit to the limit. Doing stuff that the laws were meant to stop but they found a loop hole.

Its clear to anyone with a brain who can also think critically that a 5070 is not equal to a 4090.

I also would not be surprised if in a few years or maybe a decade or so that Certain Graphic Card Company was purposefully stopping older GPUs from having significant gains in Drivers released for newer Graphic Card Generations......

Say for example certain new graphic card chip designs with new drivers show good gains over previous generation cards with an earlier design. But during testing of the driver on the previous generation they also so a good boost with the new drivers... but the gain puts it close to the numbers of the new generation card in Rasterization....

Do you think that company would put artificial limits in the driver to lower the previous generations gains with the new drivers for Rasterization Work???

I am NOT accusing any company of this either BUT there is one company that I feel is slimy enough that they would do it. Especially if they believed they'd get away with it..

I am curious... exactly when did Nvidia know many of its 50 Series GPUs did not meet the specs they claim in all their marketing etc. Super Shady....

Reminds me of what they did to the 3DFX Customers after they bought out the company. So many shady things done by most of the big tech companies over the years...

comments.text:
@NorthernWhisper  Why GPU should render all the pixels all the time? The same like video compression doesn't store all the pixels, but store only what really changed between frames. There is no reason why GPU has to render pixels for sky or landscape when there is no change in render (only position changes when you look around in the game).

Inteligent multi frame gen is the future. NVIDIA uses the same trick the video compression codecs do for decades.

comments.text:
The bashing is really unnecesery. The original 4070 was launched for 599, and this card does offer upgrade from that card (not 4070s as it is infact an improved card from 4070, and still at 599). 
Also, all testing done at the most demanding presets (like ultra etc) for a 12gb is not needed. Anyone knows that this card is meant for 1440p, and not at the ultra but high details. Sure , it looks bad , but arent we getting spoiled too much, because we have seen what 4090 and 5090 can do (for 2000usd ) and now we expect a 550$ card to do the same (like pathtracing or running at 4k with ultra details - well of course it will look disappointing. 

Its a 1440p card. the 4070 was, it was never considered for 4k gaming. And sure, you can put DLSS in performance and get the frames (even without FG) and with the new model, it will certainly look better at 4k then any PS5 game upscaled with FSR 2 or 3 .

comments.text: Also in your Operating behavior segment, there was something else odd aside from the fan RPM's. Both AIB partner cards have lower core clock than the Founders edition which is unusual because AIB partner cards will always be overclocked over stock settings meaning they run 3 to 7 percent faster than Founders. But here both Gigabyte and Asus cards are lower by as much as 45mhz core clock speeds. Something is going on. comments.text:
The old 3080Ti is going to have to stretch one more gen, it seems. Thankfully it has 50% more bandwidth and the same amount of VRAM, so I can continue playing at high settings 1440p on mainstream games that aren't shitty console ports.

I think the disappointment lacks context, though. For people wanting every generation to be a viable upgrade time, it's disappointing. But AMD is also disappointing this generation on anything outside of firesale prices on their only-midrange cards. Nvidia now has the podium with all three of the fastest GPUs in existence for consumers, which means they didn't have to push for a massive generational uplift.

And as a last thought, people who are first-time builders or who are sitting on rigs from 2016, they don't really care about generational uplift. They probably want a new model, widely compatible, do-everything GPU that plays games decently well at 1440p (or even 1080p in some people's case who don't care or only have a 1080p monitor) in the midrange price point. For them, they'll throw a 5070 in, hit their budget target, and play games with high settings at 1440p at very high framerates and be happy. You have to understand that THAT is the majority of the target market for this generation. NVidia refreshes to get a bit more performance, puts in compatibility for new AI upscaling to test it out (a la RTX20-series) and will throw the right hook next generation with the new fabrication process and new architectural changes.

Unexciting, but it fits the bill. $1500 for a full build with this card in it would make the casual gamer able to do whatever they want at 1440p with just leaving raytracing off.

So now,
- there are no more 4080 supers available
- the 5070 ti has worst performance, has no stock AND costs more
- the 5070 can't even compare in terms of performance
- the 9070xt is going to fall short in terms of 4k RT performance as well

comments.text:
If you're looking for a straightforward take: yes, the 12GB RTX 5070 paired with a GeForce NOW subscription can be a smart choice, depending on your gaming habits.

The RTX 5070 is a capable GPU for most games today, especially at 1080p and 1440p, but it might run into VRAM limits with future AAA games at ultra settings or 4K. In those cases, GeForce NOW gives you access to hardware with more VRAM and power for a relatively low cost, letting you enjoy demanding games without needing to spend big on a higher-end GPU.

It’s a good middle-ground solution if you game locally most of the time and only occasionally need the extra power. But if you’re aiming for 4K or ultra settings as a standard, you might just want to spend the extra money upfront on a GPU with 16GB+ VRAM and skip the subscription.

Let me know what your gaming setup looks like or what kind of games you play most, and I can tailor the advice further.

comments.text: I can't help but feel this is a little bit unfair. At 1440p the 5070 is 18% faster than the 4070 and is $50 lower than it at MSRP. Yes I know that prices in reality are going to be a lot more due to Nvidia's artificial scarcity but in principle I don't think that's a terrible improvement. This was demonstrated by the Cost Per Frame graph where it was way ahead of any other card listed. Is it a great card? Nope, but at MSRP it's likely to be a reasonable step up from anyone looking to upgrade from a 3000 series or older, which is what I'd assume most people would be doing. If you have a 4000 series card there's no point in upgrading, but you shouldn't need to so soon anyway.

comments.text: 🤮🤮 When I see this 5070 performing way better than a $1000 7900xtx with ray tracing enabled I get disgusted.( Even though this is unplayable territory anyways).Not because I think it is a better video card,but because to me tay tracing is garbage and that goes to show that at the end of the day it has to come down to game optimizations. Now is RT, Path Tracing, soon it'll be something else and we are back to ground cero. Imagine paying $1000 for a GPU and getting 30 fps at best when all graphics settings are maxed up including RT,PT 🤮🤮. This is just ridiculous,why do people keep falling for this kind of nonsense? I personally have a 6800xt that plays pretty much any game at 1440p, all settings max up,not RT B$, at 100+ FPS. I will never buy another GPU unless there's one available for $600 or less and that can double the performance of this 6800xt(No Frame generating B$ either)And if that day never comes that's fine with me. Newer games are trash anyways, there's 100 plus games going back 10 years that are awesome and I haven't played yet. comments.text:
I think the biggest issue isnt the vram, thats only an issue when using pathtracing in like indiana jones at 1440p and not using transformer model on performance(which looks like the original model of DLSS on quality and upscales from 480p so vram wouldnt be an issue).

Not to let Nvidia off the hook for again shorting us again $600(lol yeah right) but the glaring issue is this would be a good enough at best performance increase if it were a BASE 4060. This thing is competing with a 4070 super and consistently in almost every game getting outperformed by the 4070 Ti(not the Ti super, the Ti). The problem with this is the 4070 Ti and Ti super shouldve been the real base 4070 and 4070 super. If the 5070 is going neck and neck with the 4070 super that means its basically struggling with what shouldve been the 4060 Ti or 4060 Super. Do you see what im getting at? There’s a strong argument 5070 to be made here that the 5070 could be considered what a 5050 Ti would be, which is why the vram would be less of an issue. This below $400 dollars is a non issue. Imagine this at around $300-350?  Suddenly we’re praising the thing, but because its $600(lol) we rightfully demand atleast 16 gb but but we also should be demanding wayyyy more performance

comments.text:
to be the devil's advocate: I think people are not taking a couple of things into account:
-Nvidia is not a gaming company anymore (AI company), why they even bother to keep making GPUs for the consumer is a mystery to me
-this card is not meant for gamers, it mainly has significant improvements for small creators of smaller LLMs, SD models, Editors, and 3D render artists
-550$ MSRP (I'll belive it when I see it) is reasonable (for Nvidia) for the afromentioned productivity applications especially in the sh*tstorm inflationfest that's today's economy (GPU prices are not going to get better EVER lol)
-this card's selling point isn't raw rasterization performance (if applied for gaming) but is meant exclusively for DLSS utilization and frame gen
one big gripe I have with it though is it's thermal performance is horrendous (~77 degrees celsius) for a 250W TGP gpu, which means you NEED to have extra cooling even though the power draw is relatively low

comments.text: Also worth noting that the missing 8 ROPs are a proportionally larger performance hit for lower-end units with fewer ROPs to start with. The 5080 missing 8 ROPs takes a cut of 7.2% of its ROP count and loses up to 11% of its performance. A 5070 missing 8 ROPs would lose 10% of its ROP count, which scaling to match that 5080's worst case, would lose something like 15% of its performance.

comments.text:
@ "Devs can't optimize shit anymore"
That just isn't the Problem. Memory is cheap, there is no reason to overly optimize for it except for console compatability. The Problem here definitely is nvidia trying to force their customers to upgrade more frequently. 

As a comparison: 
in Q4 2010 the gtx 570 released with 1280MB of VRAM. In Q2 2016 the 1070 released with 8GB of VRAM (over sixfold (625%) increase over a timespan of  7 years). In Q1 2025 the rtx 5070 releases with 12 GB of VRAM (50% increase over a timespan of more than 8 years).

And this all in the context of the switch away from 1080 to 1440p(~80% more pixels) or 2160p(400% more pixels) and the addition of Raytracing which hogs VRAM and the 1070 hadn't implemented.

There is no real argument to be made, that this is a developers fault. They can't improve Visual quality and resolution and implement new lighting effects without requiring more memory capacity.

comments.text:
the problem is that the democratization of RT and Path tracing is not for now and the price is not affordable either
then in absolute in 1440p without RT/PT it works well
But the previous generations were already doing the same thing so why release products that have no interest either technically or in terms of price?

It's time for manufacturers to think about the release of their product in terms of necessity for the customer and the world like Apple with its iPhone  
Each small improvement is worth a new model if this improvement is insignificant or you can wait 6 month or 1 years if you have no performance improvement 


We all have to think about the need to buy products without any real added value for us 
The numbers are one thing but the reality of use is another, without an fps counter you can enjoy games satisfactorily even if it runs at 60 fps instead of 120 fps.i think that quality should prevail over speed of course competitive games are something else, especially for professional gamers but for the general public it doesn't make much difference. (60fps 120fps RT on RT off )
The problem is that neural textures can solve this video memory problem but without a standard it will take years.
the adoption of the various technologies no longer using DirectX takes a long time to be democratized 
I think that Microsoft preferred to invest in chat GP with financial potential much more reassuring for investors than a mature market like video games.

a bad game is still a bad game even at 240fps RT on

comments.text: For me an ideal design would be somewhat unusual 224-bit 21GB VRAM using 3GB die, and cache systems needs to be redesigned by adding massive L3 cache after L2 pool, and L2 pool reduced by half and split to leave room for L3 cache still faster than GDDR7. It might need 448MB of L3 cache to improve VRAM utilization and cut power draw further. By focusing on effective internal bandwidth with L3 cache it shall triple the effective overall bandwidth (relative to VRAM) at the same power consumption. Also future RTX cards shall skip 3nm in favor of 2nm GAAFET process for above reason

comments.text:
It would be a perfectly good card for the right price. It should also be easy for Nvidia to make an 18GB version, because once 3GB GDDR7 memory chips are available, they can just substitute those for the 2GB chips of this design without having to change any other hardware on the card. They could potentially even make a 15GB version on a narrower bus, though I think that is less likely. 

Will they actually make an 18GB version? I think there's a good chance that competition from AMD means that they are very likely to, and they might need to price it fairly competitively too. Of course, tariffs will likely ensure that you'll never see an RTX 5070 for the MSRP in the US, and that will also likely make any 18GB model cost about 650 or 700 (or more) in the US. While an 18GB model would be a lot better, it still won't be all that powerful, but at least that would give you a lot more freedom with what settings and texture quality you can use with your games.

comments.text:
Tbh all of those results are disappointing when you consider prices and how terribly optimized most of these games are. 59FPS in Wukong "1440p" with DLSS quality on a $3500 GPU is actually pretty bad.. Look at the Indiana Jones 4k results, 31FPS 1% low for the 5080 vs 28FPS 1% low for the 4080S and that's with DLSS. Both are 80 tier cards and the "generational" increase is 3FPS but costs so much more, in reality pricing not the fake MSRP. 

When you factor in the cost of a system with 9800x3D, 32gb 6000mhz CL30, 2tb 990 Pro, 1000w PSU, Asus 4k OLED with a 4090 which comes to $8660 Dolleroos.. And that's even with what the 4090 WAS selling for before it was out of stock, there is only one card available now for $6000 which is off AMZ.

If you wanted to replicate these numbers TODAY it would cost you $11159.89, for 59FPS and not even at native resolution.. If you went with a 5090 IF you could get one you would pay $7000, that's what people are asking here on Gummy, $12159.89................... 

I don't know about anybody else but this just feels like one massive scam to me.

comments.text:
Remember when Nvidia fanboys argued that my 8GB 3070 Ti VRAM was still big enough, but actually I am facing a crash problem because of a lack of video memory?

Now I have a 4070 Super with 12 GB, but there are some games that utilize around 11 GB in high settings, so I realized that the minimum today standard for high settings is 12 GB. The 70 series is a medium card that users expect to be able to play games in high or ultra settings.  When the GPU may be able to accommodate it, limited VRAM will force them to lower the game setting to medium, and 12 GB 5070 is just messy.
comments.author: @yr6sport418

comments.text:
This will also get worse over time.
 I have an old 4gb gtx 970 and in many new games it does not even bother loading in any normal textures. Some titles don't even start.

All of that despite the fact that the gpu core would still be able to give 30-60 FPS in most of these titles.

Don't dismiss vram unless you want to replace the card 1-2 years after purchase. Lack of vram can kill otherwise perfectly fine gpus.

comments.text:
I think one of my favorite ways to think about memory is that it's like a highway and the cars are what is transfering the data from one point to another.  The memory capacity is how many lanes the highway has while the speed is how fast the cars can theoretically drive.  So, for example, if someone had a sports car, it would get to the other point faster than someone driving a eco car but the problem is traffic.  Regardless of how fast that sports car is, if there are too many cars on the road, you get congestion and the sports car can only travely as fast as the fastest car on the highway.  Having more lanes on the highway allows more throughput, meaning the roads are more easily able to handle the congestion by giving more lanes to use.
The same is with Memory.  Having faster speeds does nothing if there isn't enough throughput to get the data from one point to another.  Maybe someday, a company will come up with a solution to transfer some data faster than others, like an expressway on a highway does for traffic, but that isn't here today.
16 mb should be the minimum for mid range right now as we already see 12 isn't exactly enough memory to handle the throughput.  Nvidia is cutting corners and I think it may cost them in the end.

Most people don't seem to realize the way computing power has actually worked out: We have been at theoretical limits of speed for a very long time, many many many generations. The only gains to be made are through node shrinks, which we are at the place where that is at its limit too. 

The only thing left to do is add hardware support for highest resolution gaming - 4k/8k, because those are the only places you will actually gain performance anymore.

Looking at the specs for the 5070, it was easily going to be the worst 70-class graphics card of all time. The 50 Series, except for the 5090, are just utter dogshit. Totally hardware-gimped, named multiple tiers above what they should be and stupidly overpriced. On top of that.


Melting connector issues 


Black screening due to bad drivers 


Missing ROPs, which can result in substantial performance reductions


Absolutely horrendous supply, which causes prices to skyrocket. This is seriously beyond a joke at this point, and I don't understand why idiots constantly keep forgiving Nvidia for this. It's one of the main reasons why they are able to get away with this shit. The 70-class is usually half the hardware of the 90-class/flagship. This time, the 80-class is literally half the hardware of the 90-class. The 5080 is a 5070 at best. It's more like a 5060 Ti. The 5070 literally has the specs of a 5050 Ti. Usually, the 80-class, has 60-80% of the hardware of the 90-class. Around 60-65% for the 80 and 75-80% for the 80 Ti.
comments.author: @Gamer-q7v

comments.author: @laszlozsurka8991

comments.text:
​​ @laszlozsurka8991  The 5080 gets outperformed by the 4090 by a significant margin, which is an absolute joke, and that's unforgivable. Usually, the 80-class graphics card substantially outperforms the previous-gen flagship. It's usually the 70-class graphics card that matches the previous-gen flagship. This time, the 70-class can't even match the previous-gen 80-class. This is pathetic and insulting at their best. Someone would have to be an utter fool to buy a 5070 over a 9070 or 9070 XT, both of which will absolutely annihilate the 5070 and have way more VRAM. Previous-gen Nvidia GPUs typically look like this in terms of specs compared to flagship.

50-class 15-20% of the hardware of the 90-class 

60-class 25-35% of the hardware of the 90-class 

70-class roughly 50% of the hardware of the 90-class 

80-class 60-80% of the hardware of the 90-class 

When you look at the 50 Series, you will see this isn't the case at all. So anyone who is at least relatively experienced with PC gaming will know every graphics card below the 5090 is totally hardware-gimped and named multiple tiers above what they should be. Only fanboys and idiots are stupid enough to fall for these outrageous scams.
comments.author: @Gamer-q7v

comments.text:
The thing about textures that are mapped onto surfaces of objects and characters (so 98% of textures in all the games) is that, even at 1080p, you can notice the difference between 2K and 4K textures.

They are not mapped to your screen, but to the object, so as you get closer to the object, you will be able to notice more details, regardless of your display resolution.
